name: Ada Lovelace
known_for: First Computer Programmer

Bio.Summary: The daughter of famed poet Lord Byron, Augusta Ada Byron, Countess of Lovelace — better known as "Ada Lovelace" — showed her gift for mathematics at an early age. She translated an article on an invention by Charles Babbage, and added her own comments. Because she introduced many computer concepts, Lovelace is considered the first computer programmer

Legacy: Lovelace's contributions to the field of computer science were not discovered until the 1950s. Her notes were reintroduced to the world by B.V. Bowden, who republished them in 'Faster Than Thought - A Symposium on Digital Computing Machines'. Since then, Ada has received many posthumous honors for her work.

name: Grace Hopper
known_for: Computer Scientist and Naval Officer

Bio.Summary: Grace Hopper joined the U.S. Navy during World War II and was assigned to program the Mark I computer. She continued to work in computing after the war, leading the team that created the first computer language compiler, which led to the popular COBOL language. She resumed active naval service at the age of 60, becoming a rear admiral before retiring in 1986.

Legacy: Hopper was awarded the National Medal of Technology in 1991, becoming the first female individual recipient of the honor. In addition to her programming accomplishments, Hopper's legacy includes encouraging young people to learn how to program. The Grace Hopper Celebration of Women In Computing Conference is a technical conference that encourages women to become part of the world of computing, while the Association for Computing Machinery offers a Grace Murray Hopper Award. Hopper was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom posthumously in 2016.

name: Hedy Lamarr
known_for: Inventor of WiFi

Bio.Summary: Lamarr was a self-taught inventor and film actress, who was awarded a patent in 1942 for her secret communication system, designed with the help of the composer George Antheil. This frequency hopping system was intended as a way to set radio-guided torpedos off course during the war, but the idea eventually inspired Wi-Fi, GPS and Bluetooth technology commonly used today.

Legacy: Lamarr was awarded U.S. Patent No. 2,292,387 in August of 1942. The Electronic Frontier Foundation jointly awarded Lamarr and Antheil with their Pioneer Award in 1997. Lamarr also became the first woman to receive the Invention Convention’s Bulbie Gnass Spirit of Achievement Award. Lamarr was inducted posthumously into the National Inventors Hall of Fame for the development of her frequency hopping technology in 2014.

name: Katherine Johnson
known_for: Early NASA Pioneer

Bio.Summary: West Virgina born mathematician Katherine Johnson, began her career working at the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA)’s West Area Computing unit, a group of African American women who manually performed complex mathematical calculations for the program’s engineers. She analyzed test data and provided mathematical computations that were essential to the success of the early U.S. space program. Johnson, also known as "Katherine Coleman", would continue her work at NASA where she calculated and analyzed the flight paths of many spacecraft during her more than 30 years working with the U.S. space program, including the Apollo 11 mission of 1969, that helped send astronauts to the Moon.

Legacy: Johnson has been widely recognized for her achievements through a series of awards, including but not limited to, the 1967 NASA Lunar Orbiter Spacecraft and Operations team award, and the National Technical Association’s designation as its 1997 Mathematician of the Year. Additionally, she earned honorary degrees from SUNY Farmingdale, Maryland's Capitol College, Virginia's Old Dominion University and West Virginia University. She also went on to receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015.

name: Barbara McClintock
known_for: Discovering genetic transposition (jumping genes)

Bio.Summary: McClintock was an American scientist and cytogeneticist who was awarded the 1983 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine. McClintock received her PhD in botany from Cornell University in 1927. There she started her career as the leader in the development of maize cytogenetics, the focus of her research for the rest of her life. From the late 1920s, McClintock studied chromosomes and how they change during reproduction in maize. She developed the technique for visualizing Maize chromosomes and used microscopic analysis to demonstrate many fundamental genetic ideas.

Legacy: McClintock received the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1983, the first woman to win that prize unshared and the first American woman to win any unshared Nobel Prize. It was given to her by the Nobel Foundation for discovering mobile genetic elements.

name: Elizebeth Smith Friedman
known_for: America's first female cryptanalyst

Bio.Summary: Armed with a sharp mind and nerves of steel, Elizebeth Smith Friedman cracked hundreds of ciphers during her career as America’s first female cryptanalyst, successfully busting smugglers during Prohibition and, most notably, breaking up a Nazi spy ring across South America during the 1940s.

Legacy: Elizebeth Smith Friedman’s wartime codebreaking work was so secret that she was forbidden to mention it in public. She died many years before government archives were brought to light showing what she had done. During and after World War 2, J. Edgar Hoover and the FBI took the credit for work Elizebeth and her U.S. Coast Guard team had carried out.

name: Edith Clarke
known_for: First female professor of electrical engineering in the USA

Bio.Summary: Clarke was the first woman to be professionally employed as an engineer. She was the first woman named as a Fellow of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. She specialized in electrical power system analysis. As the first woman to deliver a paper at the American Institute of Electrical Engineers' (AIEE) annual meeting, she showed the use of hyperbolic functions for calculating the maximum power that a line could carry without instability. Clarke wrote an influential textbook in the field of power engineering that was used as the basis of education for electrical engineers.

Legacy: Clarke was the first woman to earn an M.S. in electrical engineering from MIT. She was awarded a patent for her Clarke Calculator in 1925. She became the first female engineer to achieve professional standing in Tau Beta Pi. Clarke was the first female Fellow, and full voting member, of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers. She received the Society of Women Engineers Achievement Award in 1954. In 2015 Clarke was posthumously inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

name: Marie Curie
known_for: Work on radioactivity

Bio.Summary: From childhood she was remarkable for her prodigious memory, and at the age of 16 she won a gold medal on completion of her secondary education at the Russian lycée. Because her father, a teacher of mathematics and physics, lost his savings through bad investment, she had to take work as a teacher and, at the same time, took part clandestinely in the nationalist “free university,” reading in Polish to women workers. At the age of 18 she took a post as governess, where she suffered an unhappy love affair. From her earnings she was able to finance her sister Bronisława’s medical studies in Paris, with the understanding that Bronisława would in turn later help her to get an education.

Legacy: She was a famous for her work on radioactivity and twice a winner of the Nobel Prize. With Henri Becquerel and her husband, Pierre Curie, she was awarded the 1903 Nobel Prize for Physics. She was the sole winner of the 1911 Nobel Prize for Chemistry. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize, and she is the only woman to win the award in two different fields.

name: Maria Klawe
known_for: Computer scientist and fifth president of Harvey Mudd College

Bio.Summary: Toronto born naturalised American citizen Klawe holds PhDs in Mathematics and Computer Science. She worked as a researcher for IBM and became the manager of their Mathematics and Related Computer Science Department. Klawe moved to the University of British Colombia and served as head of the Department of Computer Science (1988-1995), vice president of student and academic services (1995-1998), and dean of science (1998-2002). She was on the board of directors of Microsoft from 2009-2015. Klawe is a strong advocate for increasing the representation of women in STEM fields. In 1991, she founded CRA-W (The Computing Research Association's Committee on the Status of Women in Computing Research) with Nancy Leveson.

Legacy: Klawe is a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American Mathematical Society, and the Association for Women in Mathematics. She is a founding fellow of the Canadian Information Processing Society. Klawe holds honorary doctorates from Ryerson Polytechnic University, University of Waterloo, Queen's University, Dalhousie University, Acadia University, University of Alberta, University of Ottawa, University of British Columbia, University of Toronto, Concordia University and McGill University.

name: Susan Diane Wojcicki
known_for: CEO of YouTube

Bio.Summary: Wojcicki was involved in the founding of Google, and became Google's first marketing manager in 1999. She later led the company's online advertising business and was put in charge of Google's original video service. After observing the success of YouTube, Wojcicki proposed the acquisition of YouTube by Google in 2006, and has served as CEO of YouTube since 2014

Legacy: Wojcicki first became involved with video sharing in connection with the launch of Google Video in 2005. The following year she oversaw the purchase of rival YouTube, an equally new venture that was enjoying greater success.

name: Adele Goldberg
known_for: creators of Smalltalk-80—a programming language

Bio.Summary: Adele Goldberg was one of the creator of the Smalltalk-80-a at Xeron Palo Alto Research Center, smalltalk-80 was a programming language that later incorporated into the programming configuration of the Macintosh computer. She is also the co-founder of the ParcPlace and on the board at Cognito Learning Media

Legacy: Adele Goldberg was one of the developer of the smalltalk-80, it is a programming language that developed the object-oriented approach of Simula 67 and introduced a programming environment of overlapping windows on graphic display screens,she was also involved in the development of design templates, forerunners of the design patterns later used in software design

name: Ellen Ochoa
known_for: American astronaut and first Hispanic woman to travel into space

Bio.Summary: Ochoa studied electrical engineering at Stanford University. She was selected by NASA in 1990 to participate in its astronaut program, and she became the first Hispanic female astronaut when she completed her training in 1991. In April 1993 Ochoa served as mission specialist aboard the STS-56 mission of the space shuttle Discovery, becoming the first Latina to be launched into space. In May 1999 she was a member of the Discovery STS-96 crew that executed the first docking to the International Space Station (ISS). Ochoa served as director of NASA’s Johnson Space Center (2013–18).

Legacy: Women in Aerospace Outstanding Achievement Award, Hispanic Engineer Albert Baez Award for Outstanding Technical Contribution to Humanity, Hispanic Heritage Leadership Award, Distinguished Service Medal, Exceptional Service Medal, Outstanding Leadership Medal, and four Space Flight Medals.

name: Rosalind Franklin
known_for: Discovered the molecular structure of DNA

Bio.Summary: Franklin was a British scientist best known for her contributions to the discovery of the molecular structure of deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA), a constituent of chromosomes that serves to encode genetic information. Her work to make clearer X-ray patterns of DNA molecules laid the foundation for studies on the structure of DNA as a double-helix polymer. Franklin discovered the B type DNA, establishing that DNA molecules can exist in more than one form. She also contributed new insight on the structure of viruses, helping to lay the foundation for the field of structural virology.

Legacy: Franklin received a doctorate in Physical Chemistry from Cambridge University. She was a Research Fellow at King's College. Franklin published 17 papers on viruses, and laid the foundations for structural virology. Her X-ray diffraction research of DNA became critical evidence in identifying the structure of DNA. Two scientists, Crick and Watson, took most of the credit for the finding. They used it as the basis for their famous model of DNA, for which they received a Nobel Prize in 1962.

name: Radia Joy Perlman
known_for: Invention of the Spanning-Tree Protocol, TRILL, and IS-IS

Bio.Summary: Perlman, an MIT graduate, developed the spanning-tree protocol, which greatly improved ethernet scalability. She later developed TRILL, an improvement on spanning-trees. Her IS-IS protocol is still used for IP routing, four decades later.

Legacy: Algorithms Perlman developed are still being used in network protocols today. Without her contributions, the internet would not be as robust as it is today.

name: Valerie Thomas
known_for: Inventing the illusion transmitter and contributions to NASA research

Bio.Summary: Valerie Thomas

Legacy: Thomas received a patent for the illusion transmitter. The technology was adopted by NASA and has since been adapted for use in surgery as well as the production of TV and video screens.

name: Sheryl Sandberg
known_for: Facebook COO

Bio.Summary: Sheryl Sandberg

Legacy: Sheryl Kara Sandberg is an American Business executive, Billionaire and Philanthropist.Sandberg is the chief operating officer of Facebook and the founder of LeanIn.Org. In June 2012, she was elected to Facebook's board of directors, becoming the first woman to serve on its board.

name: Rachel Louise Carson
known_for: Writer of some of the most influential environmental writing ever published

Bio.Summary: Carson was an American biologist with a deep interest in the natural world. After graduating in biology from the John Hopkins University, she pursued postgraduate studies at the Marine Biological Laboratory in Woods Hole, Massachusetts. Carson took a position as aquatic biologist with the U.S. Bureau of Fisheries. She published a number of acclaimed books. Carson’s prophetic Silent Spring (1962) became a bestseller, creating worldwide awareness of the dangers of environmental pollution. The book argued that the planetary ecosystem was reaching the limits of what it could sustain. Carson made a strong warning of the consequences of indiscriminate pesticide use.

Legacy: As a science writer, Carson published several books. Her book “The Sea Around Us” (1951) became a national bestseller and won a National Book Award, and the John Burroughs Medal for the most distinguished natural history book. “Silent Spring” (1962) also became a bestseller.

name: Laura Bassi
known_for: Bassi was the first woman to become a physics professor at a European university.

Bio.Summary: In 1732, Bassi was admitted to the Bologna Academy of Sciences as its first female member. She became doctor of philosophy. Several of her theses showed the influence of Isaac Newton’s works on optics and light. She wrote a set of theses about the properties of water, which led to her being awarded an honorary post at the university as a professor in physics. Bassi was an early proponent of Newtonian physics and based her teaching on Newton’s Principia. In 1760, Bassi performed experiments on possible medicinal applications of electricity, but did not publish on the subject. She was appointed as chair of experimental physics at the University of Bologna in 1776, the first woman named to a chair of physics at a university.

Legacy: Laura Bassi was the first woman to become a physics professor at a European university. She was the first woman admitted to the Bologna Academy of Sciences and the only woman to join the Benedettini, a select group of 25 leading scientists. She was the first woman named to a chair of physics at a university.

name: Mary Anning
known_for: Anning was the greatest fossil finder of her era, powerfully influencing the new science of paleontology

Bio.Summary: Anning was an English fossil hunter and amateur anatomist credited with the discovery of several dinosaur specimens that assisted in the development of paleontology. Her excavations aided the careers of many British scientists by providing them with specimens to study, and framed a significant part of Earth’s geologic history. Fossils recovered by Anning may have contributed to the theory of evolution put forth by Charles Darwin. Anning received annuities from the British Association for the Advancement of Science and the Geological Society of London, in recognition of her contributions to science (these did not admit women). In 2010 she was recognized by the Royal Society as one of the 10 most influential women scientists in British history.

Legacy: Anning made the first ever discovery of a complete Plesiosaurus macrocephalus skeleton. She discovered fossils of Ichthyosaur, Dimorphodon macronyx, and Squaloraja. Anning's studies of fossilized feces showed the diets of animals hundreds of millions of years ago. She was at the forefront of a new science utilizing fossils to reveal Earth’s natural history: paleontology.

name: Caroline Herschel
known_for: Herschel was a German-born British astronomer and is considered the first professional female astronomer

Bio.Summary: Herschel started her work in astronomy by making important contributions to the work of her brother Sir William Herschel, who discovered Uranus in 1781. She executed many of the calculations connected with his studies. She detected by telescope three nebulae in 1783, and in 1786 she discovered a periodic comet. She was the first woman to discover a comet; over the next 11 years she spotted seven other comets. Herschel completed the cataloging of 2,500 nebulae and many star clusters. In 1798 she presented to the Royal Society a catalog of 560 stars omitted from the British Catalogue and a list of the errata in that publication. In 1828, when Herschel was 77, the Astronomical Society awarded her its gold medal.

Legacy: Herschel was a pioneer in the field of astronomy and the first professional female astronomer. She discovered nebulae, a period comet that was later named 35P/Herschel-Rigollet, and seven more comets. Herschel made a huge contribution to indexing and cataloguing stars and nebulae and was awarded a gold medal by The Astronomical Society.

name: Maryam Mirzakhani
known_for: Mirzakhani was an Iranian mathematician and the first woman to be awarded a Fields Medal

Bio.Summary: Mirzakhani received a B.Sc. degree in mathematics from the Sharif University of Technology in Tehrān. She earned a Ph.D. from Harvard University for her dissertation 'Simple Geodesics on Hyperbolic Surfaces and Volume of the Moduli Space of Curves'. Mirzakhani served (2004–08) as a Clay Mathematics Institute research fellow and an assistant professor of mathematics at Princeton University. In 2008 she became a professor at Stanford University. Her work focused on the study of hyperbolic surfaces by means of their moduli spaces.

Legacy: Mirzakhani was the first woman and the first Iranian to be awarded a Fields Medal, in recognition of her outstanding contributions to the dynamics and geometry of Riemann surfaces and their moduli spaces. Mirzakhani found that a property of the modulus space corresponds to the number of simple closed geodesics of the hyperbolic surface.

name: Inge Lehmann
known_for: Lehmann was a Danish seismologist who discovered the inner core of Earth in 1936 by using seismic wave data. She co-founded the Danish Geophysical Society

Bio.Summary: Lehmann graduated with a cand.mag. in mathematics from the University in Copenhagen in 1920. She joined the Royal Danish Geodetic Institute, setting up Denmark’s first seismic stations near Copenhagen and in Greenland. Lehmann continued to study seismology, graduating with a magister scientiarum in 1928. She was appointed as the state geodesist and head of the Seismological Department of the Royal Danish Geodetic Institute. In 1936, she published a paper on a three-shelled model of Earth’s interior (mantle, outer core, and inner core), with seismic waves traveling through each shell at different but constant velocities. The model postulated the existence of an inner core. In 1970, advanced seismographs provided unequivocal evidence of the inner core’s existence. The boundary between the inner and outer core is known as the Lehmann discontinuity.

Legacy: The boundary between the Earth's inner and outer core, at a depth of approx. 5,100 km, is known as the Lehmann discontinuity. In 1950, Lehmann became President of the European Seismological Federation. Lehmann was awarded the William Bowie Medal of the American Geophysical Union in 1971 for her contributions in the field of geophysics, and the Medal of the Seismological Society of America in 1977. The American Geophysical Union created the Inge Lehmann Medal in her honour in 1995, to be awarded to researchers displaying “outstanding contributions to the understanding of the structure, composition, and dynamics of the Earth’s mantle and core.

name: Emmy Noether
known_for: Amalie Emmy Noether was a German mathematician whose innovations in higher algebra gained her recognition as the most creative abstract algebraist of modern times

Bio.Summary: Noether studied mathematics at the University of Erlangen at a time when women were only allowed to audit classes with the permission of the instructor. She received a Ph.D. degree in 1907, with a dissertation on algebraic invariants. Noether discovered the relation between what are known as the symmetries of a physical system and its conservation laws. This is known as Noether’s theorem and is a key result in theoretical physics. She became an academic lecturer in 1919 in a time where many objected to women teaching at universities. Noether was one of the principle architects of abstract algebra.

Legacy: Noether's name is remembered in many concepts of abstract algebra: Noetherian, Noetherian group, Noetherian induction, Noether normalization, Noether problem, Noetherian ring, Noetherian module, Noetherian scheme, Noetherian space, Albert–Brauer–Hasse–Noether theorem, Lasker–Noether theorem, and Skolem–Noether theorem. Einstein wrote after her death: “Noether was the most significant creative mathematical genius thus far produced since the higher education of women began.”

name: Margaret Hamilton
known_for: Margaret Hamilton was an American computer scientist who helped write the computer code for the command and lunar modules used on the Apollo missions to the Moon in the late 1960s and early ’70s.She is also founder and CEO of software development company Hamilton Technologies Inc.

Bio.Summary: Margaret Hamilton led the Software Engineering Division of the MIT Instrumentation Laboratory. NASA credits her with coining the term “software engineering.” Hamilton worked on software development for Apollo 11, the first spacecraft to complete a successful mission that placed humans on the moon in 1969. Hamilton's insistence on thorough testing is credited with the mission's success and safety of its astronauts.The guidance software that Hamilton helped develop for Apollo was later adapted for use in Skylab, the space shuttle, and the first digital fly-by-wire systems in aircraft. Hamilton received the NASA Exceptional Space Act Award for technical and scientific contributions in 2003 and the Presidential Medal of Freedom award in 2016.

Legacy: Margaret Hamilton is responsible for the development of the Universal Systems Language (USL) together with its integrated systems-to-software “Development Before the Fact” preventative life cycle and its automation, the 001 Tool Suite; all based on her mathematical theory of control for systems and software. Because of it's preventative paradigm, with USL, instead of looking for more ways to test for errors and continuing to test for errors late into the life cycle, the majority of errors including all interface errors are not allowed into a system, just by the way it is defined. For over five decades, Hamilton's methods have had a major impact on the field of software engineering up to and including the present day.
